The point over the right side of the abdomen that is one-third of the way between the anterior superior iliac spine and the umbilicus is known as McBurney's point. This is close to where the appendix is most frequently found.

questions.text: Following a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, a patient was released from the hospital the same day. He arrived at the hospital on the third postoperative day with a fever. A 5 X 5 cm collection was detected by ultrasonography in the right subdiaphragmatic area. What will be the management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Pigtail insertion and drainage

The given clinical scenario is of Subdiaphragmatic fluid collection and later development of abscess.
 
  • Pigtail insertion and drainage involves percutaneous placement of a catheter (pigtail) into the collection to facilitate drainage. This is a minimally invasive procedure that allows for effective drainage of the collection without the need for re-exploration or more invasive interventions.
  • By inserting the pigtail catheter, the accumulated fluid in the subdiaphragmatic area can be drained, reducing the risk of infection and promoting the patient's recovery.
  • This approach is often preferred as it carries a lower risk compared to re-exploration of the wound or more invasive procedures, while still effectively addressing the collection.
  • Observe with antibiotic cover may not be sufficient to resolve the collection, and re-exploration of the wound with T-tube insertion or ERCP may not be necessary or appropriate in this case.

Fig: Percutaneous cholecystostomy. A pigtail catheter has been placed through the abdominal wall, the right lobe of the liver, and into the gallbladder.

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1410.

questions.text:
A middle-aged woman complained of recurring bloody diarrhea. Multiple geographic ulcers are seen during colonoscopy, as seen in the histological analysis below.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Crohn’s disease

  • The histology of what appears to be a geographical ulcer is indicating a transmural inflammation, meaning it extends through the lamina propria and the muscle layer.
  • A non-caseating granuloma too is seen. Therefore, Crohn's disease is the most likely diagnosis.
  • In contrast, amoebic colitis yields a flask-shaped ulcer and pseudomembranous colitis have ischemic cryptitis and pseudo membrane on histology.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 800.

questions.text: Which of these has the highest risk of developing pancreatic cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Peutz-Jegher’s syndrome
 
  • Peutz-Jegher's syndrome is a rare autosomal dominant disorder STK 11 gene, characterized by the development of hamartomatous polyps throughout the gastrointestinal tract, including the pancreas.
  • Individuals with Peutz-Jegher's syndrome have an increased risk of developing various types of cancer, including pancreatic cancer.
  • The risk of developing pancreatic cancer in individuals with Peutz-Jegher's syndrome is estimated to be significantly higher compared to the general population.
  • It also has mucosal lentigens. 
  • Hereditary atypical multiple mole melanoma syndrome, hereditary pancreatitis, and familial adenomatous polyposis are associated with an increased risk of certain cancers but not specifically pancreatic cancer.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1309.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient was admitted with dysphagia. What is the result of the upper GI biopsy of the esophagus indicated in the following image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Barrett’s esophagus
 
  • The result of the upper GI biopsy of the esophagus indicated in the image is consistent with Barrett's esophagus.
  • Barrett's esophagus is a condition characterized by the replacement of the normal squamous epithelium of the lower esophagus with specialized intestinal-type columnar epithelium (intestinal metaplasia).
  • It is commonly associated with chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and is a premalignant condition for the development of esophageal adenocarcinoma.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 761.

questions.text: A road traffic accident victim arrived at the hospital with a contusion on the anterior chest wall, a heart rate of 90 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 120/80 millimeters, and a respiratory rate of 16 beats per minute. Normal heartbeats can be heard; however, the trachea is twisted to the right and breath sounds are less audible on the left. Which of the following is the definitive of management??
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is 3. Chest tube insertion and drainage

Thoracic decompression should be rapidly performed with a large-bore needle or tube thoracostomy, depending on the availability of equipment and supplies.  But in Clinical setting, Needle Thoracostomy is used mostly for Unstable patient. In the above question patient is hemodynamically stable with decreased breath sound on one side, Tube thoracostomy is indicated.

In tension pneumothorax, air accumulates in the pleural space under pressure, causing mediastinal shift and compression of the lung, which can lead to cardiovascular collapse if untreated.

Deviation of the trachea in the sternal notch with unilaterally absent or diminished breath sounds and cardiopulmonary compromise should immediately suggest tension pneumothorax.

Needle thoracostomy involves inserting a large-bore needle (usually 14 or 16 gauge) into the pleural space at the second intercostal space midclavicular line on the affected side to relieve the pressure and restore lung function.

External landmarks for reliable placement should include the level of the nipple or inframammary fold inferiorly, midaxillary line posteriorly, and the hypotenuse of the two sides (“triangle of safety”). After infusion of local analgesia, a skin incision roughly equivalent to the circumference of the chest tube should be made within the triangle at or just above the level of the nipple (5th–6th intercostal spaces).

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 375.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient comes in with fever, diarrhea, and intense abdominal pain that lasts for six hours. As seen, an erect abdominal X-ray was taken. What is the most probable diagnosis?

  • The most probable diagnosis for the patient with fever, diarrhea, and intense abdominal pain seen in the erect abdominal X-ray is toxic megacolon.
  • Toxic megacolon is a potentially life-threatening condition characterized by severe inflammation and dilation of the colon, usually due to severe infection or inflammatory bowel disease.
  • It can present with symptoms such as abdominal pain, fever, diarrhea, and signs of systemic toxicity.

questions.text: A woman who had a normal vaginal delivery returned after five days with a headache/vomiting. Papilledema was visible in the fundus. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Cortical vein thrombosis
 
  • The most likely diagnosis for the woman who had a normal vaginal delivery and presented with headache/vomiting and papilledema visible in the fundus is cortical vein thrombosis.
  • Cortical vein thrombosis is a form of cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (CVST) where blood clots form in the veins draining the cerebral cortex.
  • It can lead to increased intracranial pressure, resulting in symptoms such as headache, vomiting, and visual disturbances.

questions.text: In case of endometriotic lesions, histology represents its?
questions.solution:
Positive estrogenic activity, or a hormonal environment, is often believed to aide the growth of the endometrial cells and contribute to the histopathology of endometriosis. 

Pathogenesis/Pathophysiology of Endometriosis.
 
  • Theory of retrograde menstruation (implantation theory or transplantation theory)-  most widely accepted theory.
  • This theory proposes that endometriosis results from endometrial cells that are transported via the fallopian tubes in backward menstrual flow, known as retrograde menstruation. The endometrial cells which enter the pelvic cavity can then attach
  • themselves to the pelvic structures and grow, developing into endometriotic lesions. 
  • Positive estrogenic activity aids in the growth of endometrial cells into endometriotic lesions. 




Reference: Williams Obstetrics 26th edition Page no 235.

questions.text: Anti-D was given to a Rh-negative mother who had a negative Indirect Coombs Test (ICT) at 28 weeks of pregnancy. Which of the following is the best option?
questions.solution:
Give another dose of Anti-D 72 hours postpartum depending on the baby blood group
In RAADP ( Routine antenatal Anti D Prophylaxis) , anti D is administered at 28 weeks and then within 72 hours post partum if the baby is Rh positive.
 
  • Fetomaternal hemorrhage at delivery accounts for as many as 90 percent of alloimmunization cases.
  • Routine postpartum administration of anti-D immune globulin to at-risk pregnancies within 72 hours of delivery lowers the alloimmunization rate by 90 percent. Additionally, provision of anti-D immune globulin at 28 weeks gestation reduces the third-trimester alloimmunization rate.
  • Whenever there is doubt whether to give anti-D immune globulin, it should be given.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 356, 357.

questions.text: What is the next step in managing a 32-year-old woman with bilateral tubal block seen at cornu on a hysterosalpingogram and a five-year history of primary infertility?

  • Sometimes during HSG there can be a cornual spasm which can give a wrong impression of cornual block .

Mullerian abnormalities :- 
Type 1 :- MRHK or Mullerian agenesis

- mc type

questions.text: A woman who is 36 weeks pregnant is admitted to your ward. She is depicted in the illustration lying supine during the morning rounds. She complains of faintness and lightheadedness. Which syndrome is pictured below?
questions.solution:
• Supine hypotensive syndrome/Supine vena cava syndrome (also referred to as inferior vena cava compression syndrome) is caused when the gravid uterus compresses the inferior vena cava when a pregnant woman is in a supine position, leading to decreased venous return centrally.
  • That's why pregnant women are advised to lie in left lateral position.
 

Supine Hypotension Syndrome is a condition that can occur during pregnancy, particularly in the later stages, when the heavy uterus compresses the inferior vena cava (IVC) while the woman is lying flat on her back. This compression reduces venous return to the heart, leading to decreased cardiac output and hypotension.

  • Symptoms: Dizziness, lightheadedness, weakness, nausea, palpitations, and in severe cases, fainting (syncope).
  • Mechanism: Lying supine compresses the IVC, impairing blood flow back to the heart.
  • Risk Factors: More common after 20 weeks of pregnancy; overweight women may be at higher risk.
  • Management: Shift to a left lateral position or elevate the right hip to relieve pressure on the IVC.
  • Prevention: Pregnant women should avoid lying flat on their backs for prolonged periods, especially in the third trimester.
 


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 64.

questions.text: Which statement regarding congenital CMV infection is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: It is the most common cause on nonsyndromic sensory neural hearing loss

Option 1 : Prenatal diagnosis includes the presence of IgM antibodies in the mother. Postnatal diagnosis involves isolation of the virus from Urine or Saliva via DNA PCR or culture within first few weeks of life. Thus the first option is incorrect.

Option 2 : Is the true statement. CMV infection stands out as the most common non-genetic cause of sensorineural hearing loss. Other infections that can cause congenital SNHL are toxoplasmosis, rubella.

Option 3 : Congenital CMV infection is mostly asymptomatic at birth and symptoms occur only in about 10% of neonates. Asymptomatic newborns have a lesser risk of sequale as compared to others.

Option 4 : Although the risk of transmission of infection is higher in symptomatic females, in most populations the total number of infants who have acquired an infection is 3-4 times more from asymptomatic mothers than symptomatic as the number of females with active CMV infection are less and most are asymptomatic.

Thus, option 2 stands out as the most correct option among all others.

Some points about Congenital CMV infection
  • Infants present with petichial rashes, jaundice, chorioretinitis, HSaM.

questions.text: A 5-year-old who had previously experienced loose stools but no fever or blood in the feces was brought to the hospital. questions.solution:
The given child has features suggestive of SOME dehydration. (Irritability/agitation/increased thirst/sunken eyes and delayed skin pinch).



In some dehydration - we use PLAN B - give 75ml/kg of ORS over 4 hours - which can be given orally/NG along with zinc to reduce the duration of diarrhoea. 



Hence, the best answer is option 4- Give Zinc supplementation and Oral rehydration solution and ask the mother to come back if some danger signs develop

Other Options

Option 1 - IV antibiotics and referral to higher centre according to IMNCI is done if child has severe pneumonia or very severe disease(presence of danger signs), not for some dehydration

Option 2 - Since child has some dehydration - we need to give ORS, not just oral fluids. Zn supplementation is also necessary in view of diarrhoea. 

Option 3 - IV Fluids are given in severe dehydration - however, the clinical signs in question stem are suggestive of some dehydration , not severe.

questions.text: One year after having cataract surgery, a 63-year-old patient complains of having worse eyesight. The clinical image seen below was discovered. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: After cataract.
 
  • Posterior capsular opacification also called "after" or "secondary" cataract is the opacity that follows extracapsular extraction of the lens. 
  • In this surgery, the posterior capsule and part of the anterior capsule are left in situ which almost always has remnants of the capsule. 
  • The rate of posterior capsule opacification following extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) and phacoemulsification varies with the age of the patient, the surgeon, the surgical technique, the type of intraocular lens used, and the duration after surgery.
 
Other options: 
  • UGH syndrome (B): A rare complication of cataract surgery, causing glare, blurred vision, and pigment dispersion.
  • Irvine-Gass syndrome (C): Also known as pseudophakic cystoid macular edema, it involves the accumulation of fluid in the macula after cataract surgery, leading to decreased vision and potential distortions.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 410, 411.

questions.text:
The eye was photographed as shown below. It displays abrasion, foreign body, ulcer, and perforation of the cornea. All can cause hypotonic maculopathy,
with the exception of:
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1: Suprachoroidal hemorrhage.
 
  • Hypotonic maculopathy refers to the swelling and dysfunction of the macula due to chronic low intraocular pressure (IOP) less than 6 mm Hg.
  • It can occur as a complication of ocular conditions involving corneal abrasion, foreign body, ulcer, or perforation.
  • Suprachoroidal hemorrhage refers to bleeding between the choroid and the sclera, typically caused by trauma or surgical complications.
  • While suprachoroidal hemorrhage can lead to elevated intraocular pressure (hypertony), it does not directly cause hypotonic maculopathy.
 
Other options:
  • The most common cause is excessive drainage following glaucoma filtration surgery (option D). 
  • Other causes include trauma such as cyclodialysis of uvea (option C), penetrating injury (option B), chronic uveitis, retinal detachment and other systemic causes such as dehydration, uncontrolled diabetes, uraemia and treatment with hyperosmotic agents. They usually cause bilateral hypotonic maculopathy.


Reference: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, Page no 326, 327, 610.

questions.text: Which ophthalmological study is being conducted in this illustration?
questions.solution:

GAT is based on the Imbert–Fick principle, which states that the force necessary to applanate a perfectly elastic, infinitely thin, dry sphere divided by the area flattened (P = F/A) equals the pressure inside the sphere.

questions.text: A young girl who had experienced spotty hair loss for two weeks presented to the OPD as depicted below. Both erythema and scarring were absent. What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Trichotillomania
  • The given image shows patchy hair loss with hair of various lengths pointing towards a diagnosis of trichotillomania. Trichotillomania is non scarring alopecia characterised by perifollicular haemorrhage.
  • Trichotillomania is a disorder characterized by the compulsive pulling of hair.
  • It is predominantly seen in females and is almost always associated with psychological or behavioral stress disorders like OCD (obsessive-compulsive disorder), Body dysmorphic disorder, intellectual disability, etc. 
  • It presents as an area of patchy hair loss, often in a bizarre pattern.
  • The hairs are often twisted and broken at varying lengths or may be present as uniform, coarse stubble. The scalp skin appears normal.
  • Sites other than the scalp can also be affected, for example - eyelashes, eyebrows, beard, mons pubis, and perianal region.
  • Patients sometimes may swallow/eat the hair and present in intestinal obstruction. (Bezoar)

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 86.17, 86.18

questions.text: Which of the following facial congenital lesions is present?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Congenital melanocytic nevus
 
  • The given image showing a black, heterogeneous, hairy palpable lesion in a child is suggestive of congenital melanocytic nevus. 
  • Congenital melanocytic nevi (CMN) are benign, pigmented, melanocytic nevi present at birth.
  • They are most commonly brown, black, purplish, or red, usually a palpable lesion with heterogeneous color and texture.
  • CMN often have thick hair at birth, which grows at a significantly greater rate than the surrounding scalp hair.

questions.text: As seen in the illustration below, an 11-year-old boy had plaques in his cubital and popliteal fossa that were itchy and hyperpigmented. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:

  • The given clinical history of plaques over the popliteal and cubital fossae suggests the diagnosis of atopic dermatitis.
  • Atopic dermatitis is the cutaneous expression of the atopic state, characterized by a family history of asthma, allergic rhinitis, or eczema.
  • The epidermal barrier is impaired due to a mutation in the gene encoding filaggrin (a structural protein in the stratum corneum).
  • The site of lesions shifts to elbow and knee flexures when the child is 18 months to 2 years.
  • There is also a mixture of erythema, crusting, excoriation, hyper- and hypopigmentation, and warty lichenification seen on the sides of the neck, wrists, and ankles. 
  • Below are the differences between Atopic dermatitis and Psoriasis.

questions.text: A patient's complex kidney cyst was unintentionally discovered on ultrasound, and as a result, he received a CT for an insurance workup. What is the most probable diagnosis
questions.solution:
Because most angiomyolipomas contain substantial amounts of adipose tissue, therefore it appears hypodense in the CECT image.

US shows a bright echogenic mass lesion on account of the high fat content. CT scan shows an intralesional fat density of –15 to –20 Hounsfield units (HU) within the mass, which is the hallmark of an angiomyolipoma radiological diagnosis. Management depends upon the size of the tumour, the risk of haemorrhage (Wonderlich syndrome) and the symptoms.

Angiomyolipomas are seen in Tuberous Sclerosis complex. 

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1481.

questions.text: An ultrasound was requested by a 65-year-old male banker in order to renew his health insurance. A complicated cyst was discovered in the right kidney, and hence underwent a CT. The CT scan image is shown below. The most likely possibility is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Renal cell carcinoma
 
  • The CT scan image shows a solid mass with irregular borders in the right kidney, which is highly suspicious for renal cell carcinoma.
  • Renal cell carcinoma is the most common type of kidney cancer, accounting for approximately 85% of all cases.
  • Contrast-enhanced CT is the investigation of choice for RCC. On CT, small lesions enhance homogeneously, whereas larger lesions have irregular enhancement due to areas of necrosis.
  • The clear cell subtype may show much stronger enhancement is a differential for angiomyolipoma. Below is the CT of Angiomyolipoma.




Other options:
 
  • Oncocytoma and angiomyolipoma are benign renal tumors that usually have well-defined borders and a characteristic appearance on imaging.
  • Perinephric cysts are fluid-filled sacs located adjacent to the kidney and appear as simple cystic lesions on imaging.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1482.

questions.text:
A young female with history of renal calculi complains of bone pain and abdominal cramps.
Multiple fractures were identified during the study, and serum calcium and PTH levels were elevated. Which of the following will be the best inquiry to arrive at a conclusive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Sestamibi scan
 
  • The clinical presentation of bone pain, abdominal cramps, elevated serum calcium, and elevated PTH levels suggests the possibility of hyperparathyroidism.
  • Sestamibi scan is the imaging of choice for diagnosing primary hyperparathyroidism.
  • It is also known as a parathyroid scan, & is the best inquiry to localize the source of abnormal parathyroid activity.
  • The scan involves injecting a radioactive tracer that is selectively taken up by hyperactive parathyroid glands, allowing for their identification.
Other options:
 
  • CECT neck and ultrasound neck can provide additional information, but they are not the primary diagnostic modalities for hyperparathyroidism.
  • Radioiodine scan is used to evaluate thyroid function and is not directly relevant to the diagnosis of hyperparathyroidism.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 877.

questions.text: A patient with abdominal pain for 2 hours arrives to the casualty, and the following X-ray is obtained. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Pneumoperitoneum
 
  • The X-ray shows air under the diaphragm, which indicates the presence of free air within the peritoneal cavity, known as the pneumoperitoneum.
  • Pneumoperitoneum is most commonly caused by a perforated viscus, such as a ruptured hollow organ (e.g., stomach, intestine) or iatrogenic injury during surgery.

Fig: Pneumoperitoneum on upright chest X-ray in patient with perforated ulcer



Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1127.

questions.text: The X-ray of the chest shown below exhibits all of the traits except:
questions.solution:
The X-ray suggests cardiomegaly, right atrial enlargement, and decreased blood flow, possibly
due to some right-sided valvular obstruction like Ebstein anomaly. There are no signs of
pulmonary hypertension in the X ray. 
The appearance known is Box shaped heart.




Reference: Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 9th edition, Page no 420, 421.

questions.text: Which of the following is an anti-suicidal mood stabiliser?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Lithium
 
  • Lithium is a mood stabilizer with anti-suicidal properties. It is the DOC in prophylaxis of BPD.
  • It acts by decreasing the levels of excitatory neurotransmitters like Glutamate and increases the activity of GABA. It also downregulates the NMDA receptors.
* Some important values related to lithium


Valproate is given to rapid cyclers in BPD. Carbamazepine and Lamotrigine are also effective in BPD but none of them reduce the suicidal tendencies.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 378.

questions.text: The following best describes a state of mutism and akinesis in which the patient is only somewhat alert:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Stupor

Stupor
Stupor is a condition in which a person is almost completely nonresponsive and reacts only to strong stimuli, like pain. It is characterized by the absence of critical mental function and a very small degree of consciousness. The patient is usually mute/akinetic.

Definition of other terms

Delirium
A disordered state of awareness or of the mind, especially a sudden, a brief condition brought on by fever, intoxication, or other physical conditions, and characterized by symptoms like confusion, agitation, disorientation, and hallucinations.

Oneroid State
The psychopathological condition known as oneiroid syndrome (OS), also known as dream-like delusional derangement of consciousness, is characterized by a kaleidoscopic quality of psychopathological experiences in which reality, illusions, and hallucinations are combined into one.

Twilight State
An altered state of consciousness in which the person is momentarily ignorant of his or her surroundings has momentary auditory or visual hallucinations and reacts to them by acting irrationally, such as stripping off in public, fleeing, or inflicting harm.



Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 341.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman fantasies about chopping her fingers, plots for it, and even attempts it, but she never follows through. She claims that she doesn't feel bad about thinking such things. Additionally, she claims that she is helpless to stop the upsetting thoughts. Either a seizure ends the thoughts, or they naturally stop on their own. What one of the following is the reason?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. FORCED THINKING
 
  • The given clinical vignette describes Forced thinking which includes different types of intrusive thoughts. These are the most common pre-ictal events, commonly seen in Frontal Lobe Epilepsy.
  • Obsession is a type of intrusive thought that is recurrent, persistent, and unwanted. The person experiences these thoughts as distressing and anxiety-provoking, and they often attempt to neutralize them by performing compulsive behaviors. Obsession is Ego Dystonic, hence patient feels distressed with these thoughts but in the above scenario patient does not feel bad about these thoughts hence it is unlikely to be obsession.
  • Thought insertion is defined by the ICD-10 as the delusion that one's thoughts are not one's own, but rather belong to someone else and have been inserted into one's mind.


Reference: Lishman's Organic Psychiatry, 4th edition, Page no 557.
Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page no 251.

questions.text: The relationships of the epiploic foramen are displayed in the abdomen's subsequent coronal section. According to the illustration below, which of the following structures constitutes its superior boundary?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Caudate lobe of the liver
 
  • The epiploic foramen, also known as the foramen of Winslow, is a small opening in the peritoneum that connects the lesser sac to the greater sac.
  • The superior boundary of the epiploic foramen is formed by the caudate lobe of the liver.
  • The caudate lobe is one of the lobes of the liver and lies posteriorly, adjacent to the inferior vena cava.

   Boundaries of epiploic foramen :
  






Reference-: https://radiopaedia.org/articles/epiploic-foramen-1

questions.text: The cervical vertebra is illustrated as follows. Which portion is connected to the third segment of the vertebral artery?
questions.solution:
A - Transverse Foramnen
B - Anterior Arch
C- Groove for vertebral artery
D- Superior Articular facet

The vertebral artery has 4 segments
V1: Origin ---> C6 transverse foramen.
V2: Transverse foramen of C6---->Transverse foramen of C2
V3: Atlantic segment - related to the atlas(C1). It lies in the groove on the upper surface of the posterior arch of the atlas.
V4:  Intradural segment.


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 589,590
